columns.text: In this problem, we will discuss the concept of policy extension and determine whether extending the given policy will be beneficial to the company long term.

Usually, when selling a product, the payment is made upfront before the product is even released to the customer. However, when offering a credit policy, the customer gets to pay for the product at a later date but they will get the product immediately.

In order to determine whether they should extend credit policy to their customers, we need to solve for the net present value. This can be done by first solving for the cash flow for the customers that will return and the cash flow for the one-time customers. 

To solve for the cash flow of the customers that will return, we can use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\dfrac{\text{Quantity} \times \text{Percentage of return customers} \times (\text{Credit price}-\text{Variable cost})}{\text{Required return}}
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\dfrac{125 \times 0.30 \times (\$7,600-\$6,900)}{0.019}\\[15 pt]
&=\$138,157.89
\end{aligned}$$

The cash flow from returning customers is $\$138,157.89$.

We will then solve for the cost of producing all these products. This can be done by using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\text{Quantity}\times\text{Variable costs}\\[15 pt]
&=125 \times\$6,900\\[15 pt]
&=\$862,500
\end{aligned}$$

The cost of producing all the orders is $\$862,500$.

We can then solve for the net present value by subtracting the costs from the total cash flow. Our net present value will then be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\text{Cash flow from returning customers}\\
&+\text{Cash flow from one-time customers}\\
&-\text{Costs}\\[15 pt]
&=\$138,157.89+\$652,600.59-\$862,500\\[15 pt]
&=-\$71,741.52
\end{aligned}$$

Since the net present value is negative, then the credit should not be extended since it does not create profit for the company.
